alt_statements.statement: As someone who runs my own small business and has a family to protect, I think tech companies have a serious responsibility to treat user data like something sacred, not just a product to be squeezed for profit. They should be required to explain clearly—in plain language—what they collect, why, and how it’s sold or shared, and people should have a real choice to opt out without losing access to essential services. I also believe there should be strong legal protections and independent oversight to prevent abuse, because the folks most likely to be exploited are often from minority communities like mine. In Christian terms, if you’re going to profit from people’s information, you should do it with honesty, consent, and respect for their dignity.

As a conservative and a family man, I believe tech companies have a serious responsibility to treat users’ data with the same care they’d want for their own children’s information—collecting only what is truly necessary and being completely transparent about how it’s used. They should never sell or share personal data in ways that could harm people’s privacy, security, or dignity, and there must be clear consequences when they abuse that trust. Especially for immigrants and people without strong legal protections, tech companies should not exploit our data just to make more profit, but respect our rights and our private lives.

As someone who works with physical materials and sees how every scrap can be reused, I think tech companies need to treat our data less like a resource to strip-mine and more like something entrusted to them with clear limits and respect. At a minimum, they should be fully transparent about what they’re collecting, get meaningful consent, protect it like a bank protects money, and never sell or share it in ways people didn’t clearly agree to. If they’re going to profit from our data, we should have real control over it, the right to easily opt out, and strong legal protections when they abuse that power.

As someone who works with people’s information every day in a library, I think tech companies should treat user data more like we treat patron records: as something private and not to be used without clear, informed consent. They should be upfront and plainspoken about what they collect, how they profit from it, and give users easy, real choices to opt out. There also need to be strong protections so this data isn’t used to manipulate people or discriminate against them, especially kids and vulnerable groups.

I don’t think there’s anything wrong with tech companies using data to keep the lights on, but they ought to be straight with people about what they’re collecting and how they’re making money off it. At the very least, users should get clear, plain-language explanations and an easy way to opt out of certain uses without losing basic access to services. I’m not big on heavy-handed regulation, but if companies can’t be honest and responsible on their own, then some reasonable rules to protect privacy and prevent abuse make sense.

As someone who’s spent a career caring for people, I think tech companies should treat our personal data with the same duty of care—using it only with clear consent, strong privacy protections, and honest explanations in plain language. I don’t mind them making money, but they should never sell or share information in ways that could harm people or exploit vulnerable groups, and they should be held legally accountable when they break that trust.

As someone who’s spent a career teaching and doing research, I think tech companies should treat user data with the same rigor and respect we apply to human subjects in academia: informed consent, transparency about how data is used and monetized, and strict limits on secondary uses. The default shouldn’t be “collect everything and apologize later,” but minimal, clearly disclosed collection that users can easily opt out of without losing essential services. Given how vulnerable people can be to manipulation and surveillance, there should be strong legal and ethical guardrails—independent audits, real penalties for abuse, and user ownership over their own data.

As someone who works in a school and has kids of my own, I think tech companies have a responsibility to treat our data like they should treat our children—protect it first, profit from it second, if at all. They should be required to clearly explain what they’re collecting, get real consent (not buried in fine print), and never sell or use data in ways that could harm people, especially kids or vulnerable communities. I also believe there should be strong government oversight and meaningful penalties when companies break these rules, because without that, they’ll always be tempted to put profit over people.

If tech companies are going to collect and profit from our data, they should be upfront, in plain English, about exactly what they’re taking and how it’s being used, and give us real, easy-to-use options to say no. I work with sensitive information every day at the hospital, and we’re held to strict rules to protect people’s privacy—big tech should be held to at least that standard, with strong legal consequences when they abuse our trust.

As someone who came to the U.S. for better opportunities and works hard just to get by, I think tech companies have a serious responsibility not to exploit people’s data just because we clicked “accept” on a long, confusing policy. If they’re going to profit from our information, they should be crystal clear about what they collect, how they use it, and give us real, simple choices to opt out. They should also be legally required to protect that data from abuse and discrimination, especially for immigrants, low-income workers, and other vulnerable groups who can’t afford lawyers or fancy privacy tools. In my view, if a tech company makes money off our data, a portion of that profit should go toward public good—like funding digital literacy, community programs, and accessible privacy protections.

In my restaurant, if I take customer information for reservations or loyalty cards, I must treat it like fresh fish—handle it carefully, use only what’s needed, and never sell it off behind their backs. Tech companies should do the same: be honest and simple about what data they take, get real consent, protect it like it’s their own family recipe, and share the profit more fairly when they make big money from people’s information. I think tech companies should ask us clearly before they take our information, and explain it in simple words kids can understand, not tiny confusing writing. Since my parents and teachers tell me to be honest and careful with other people’s things, I think companies should have to be honest and careful with our data too, especially for kids.

As someone who makes a living analyzing processes, I think tech companies should be held to a standard of radical transparency and strict accountability when it comes to collecting and monetizing user data. Given how central tech is to our democracy and everyday life, I believe there should be strong federal regulations, meaningful enforcement, and serious financial consequences when companies misuse or fail to protect people’s data.

As someone who’s spent a lifetime catching other people’s mistakes in print, I’m keenly aware of how the fine print can be used to hide abuses, and that’s exactly what too many tech companies do with user data. If they’re going to collect and profit from our information, they should be legally required to get clear, informed consent, minimize what they collect, and give us simple tools to see, correct, and delete it. As someone who has spent a lifetime organizing in my community and fighting for dignity and fairness, I believe tech companies have a responsibility to treat our personal data with the same respect they’d want for their own families. When companies make billions off our information, they owe us strong privacy protections, independent oversight, and clear accountability when they abuse our trust.

As someone who’s worked hard all my life and lives simply, I don’t think it’s right for tech companies to quietly profit off people’s personal information without clear permission and strong protections. I think tech companies should ask people very clearly before they use our information, and explain it in simple words kids and parents can both understand. If these big tech companies are going to collect our data and make money off it, they ought to be straight with us about what they’re taking, how they’re using it, and give us a real choice to opt out. Tech companies shouldn’t be allowed to just grab our data and sell it without us clearly knowing and agreeing, because that feels like a big invasion of privacy and family life. Tech companies have a responsibility to be completely transparent about what data they collect, how they use it, and with whom they share it, in language the average person can actually understand. While I support free markets and innovation, I think there must be firm legal limits against selling or abusing sensitive personal information, especially when it comes to our finances, health, and political views. As someone who’s spent a lifetime working with people face-to-face, I think tech companies ought to treat our data with the same respect I give a customer signing a contract—plain language, no tricks, and no hidden fine print. I think if people on the computer give their secrets or pictures, the tech people shouldn’t be allowed to just sell them or spy on them without asking first. If people on computers take our stuff, they should ask first and say what they’re going to do with it in words kids and grown-ups can understand. They shouldn’t be allowed to sell or share things about us that could hurt us, like where we live or what we like, without our parents saying it’s okay.

As someone who’s pretty tech-savvy but also just trying to raise a young family on a modest income, I think tech companies have a serious responsibility to be transparent and honest about how they collect and use our data. At my age, I’ve seen enough to know that when companies say “trust us,” you’d better read the fine print, especially with something as personal as our data. If tech companies are going to collect and profit off our data, they should be completely transparent about what they’re taking, how they’re using it, and who they’re selling it to—in language regular people can actually understand. I think tech companies should be honest and clear about what they’re doing with our data, especially because a lot of young people like me don’t always understand all the fine print. As someone who’s tried to live simply and tread lightly on the planet, I think tech companies have a responsibility to collect the absolute minimum data they truly need, and to explain clearly—in plain English—what they’re doing with it. As someone who works with sensitive medical equipment, I think tech companies should treat user data with the same level of care and precision—collect only what’s truly necessary, secure it tightly, and be upfront and honest about how it’s used. Tech companies shouldn’t be allowed to just grab our data and sell it without us really knowing what’s going on. I think tech companies should have to ask clearly before they take our data, and explain it in words kids and adults can both understand, not in super long, confusing paragraphs. Tech companies have a responsibility to be upfront and honest about what data they collect, why they’re collecting it, and who they’re selling it to—no fine print games. Tech companies have a duty to be upfront and honest about what data they collect, how they use it, and who they sell it to—no fine print tricks or hidden settings. As someone who builds software for a living, I think tech companies have a responsibility to collect only the data they actually need, explain clearly how it’s used, and give users real control over what’s shared and monetized. As a mom and small business owner, I think tech companies have a basic duty to treat our personal data like they’d want their own kids’ information treated—carefully, honestly, and with clear limits. As someone who cares a lot about health and privacy, I think tech companies have a responsibility to collect only the data they truly need, explain clearly how it will be used, and get real, informed consent—not bury it in legalese. As a mom, a teacher, and someone who spends a lot of time online for both work and home, I think tech companies have a serious responsibility to treat our data like something precious, not something to be exploited. Tech companies should treat people’s data like something sacred, not just a way to make money, especially for kids and teens who don’t always understand what they’re giving up. As someone who works for a private company and values personal responsibility and privacy, I think tech companies have a duty to be upfront and honest about what data they collect, how they use it, and who they share it with—no fine-print tricks. From my perspective, if they’re making a profit off people’s data, there should be clear limits and accountability, not just “trust us” from big corporations.

Tech companies should treat user data like they’d want their own family’s information treated: with strict privacy, clear consent, and no sneaky fine print. If they’re going to make money off our data, they ought to be upfront about exactly what they collect, how they use it, and give us real options to opt out, not just a maze of settings. I’d also support strong laws that hold them legally and financially accountable when they misuse data or fail to protect it from hackers.

As someone who has spent a career advising clients on risk, consent, and obligations, I believe tech companies should be held to a clear, enforceable standard of transparency and accountability when collecting and monetizing user data. I’m not looking for heavy-handed government micromanagement, but I do support well-defined legal guardrails and real consequences for deception or misuse, so that the market can function on informed consent rather than hidden fine print.

Tech companies have a responsibility to be upfront and honest about what data they collect, how they use it, and who they share it with—no sneaky fine print. As someone who spent a lifetime teaching young people to think critically and treat others with respect, I believe tech companies have a moral duty to be transparent and honest about how they collect and use our data.
